CharacterMenuJourney2Simplify: ^See how Bing Bing, Bowen, and Jennifer simplify
BBSimplify1: ^I started with a smaller problem and wrote it in my journal.
BBSimplify3: ^But when I read it out loud, I knew it wasn't clear or specific enough. Trying to rewrite it was frustrating, so I took a break and walked around the block before coming back to my journal.
BBSimplify4: ^I had to describe the problem objectively, like the way I would talk to a colleague about an issue at work. Once I got it on paper, I was able to break down my problem.
BBSimplify6: ^From there, I made a list of all the smaller parts that contributed to the problem.
BowenSimplify1: ^I used the simplify steps to plan out the work I need to do for each of my action plan solutions. It felt good to see the steps and know that I'm getting closer to my goals.
BowenSimplify2: ^One of my solutions was to talk to a financial planner, so I sat down with my wife and we talked through each action that it would take.
BowenSimplify4: ^After breaking down each step, working out a solution doesn't seem like such a big load anymore.
JenniferSimplify1: ^As a start, I wanted to practice this tool to help me simplify communications with my parents. First, I described the problem clearly in my journal. I had to keep it simple, which took me a few tries!
JenniferSimplify2: ^The problem is that I have a habit of setting unrealistic expectations for my relationship with my parents. So, I ask myself: "Is this practical?" AND "Is it achievable?" for each step.
JenniferSimplify4: ^I had to think strategically about how and when I would engage with my parents, and add in enough time to step back and recharge.
